citations.narrative:
The disposition records are not current or complete at the time of inspection. There is no documentation available to
review for the disposition of a zebra, a raccoon and three opossums that occurred since the last inspection. Accurate and
complete acquisition and disposition records are necessary to allow for medical and legal tracking of the animals. The
facility shall ensure that it makes, keeps, and maintains records which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning all exhibition animals: name and address of person from whom an animal was acquired, their USDA license
number or Driver's license number/state, the name and address of the disposition of the animal, the date of acquisition
and/or disposition, and the species of the animal.
Corrected at time of inspection.

The facility has not yet completely developed and documented a contingency plan. A written contingency plan is required
to help ensure animal health and well-being in the event of an emergency or disaster; without this tool, animals may suffer
illness, injury, or death due to unpreparedness should an emergency or disaster strike. The licensee must develop,
document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and
care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. The plan must also be reviewed annually, and all
employees trained on the plan within 30 days of employment.
Corrected at time of inspection.

Medical records were incomplete for both dog hybrids. Per the licensee, “Luna” and “Kuda” were both prescribed a
monthly heartworm medication but there is no medical record showing any medication was prescribed or any treatments
were given. Also, "Kuda" was prescribed an ear medication on January 10, 2023, with no record of doses being given by
the licensee. The licensee stated all medications had been given as prescribed. Medical recordkeeping is important for
ensuring the dog hybrids receive correct and complete medical care as well as assist with monitoring. Incomplete records
can lead to missed or incorrect treatments, which can cause medical conditions to worsen. The facility shall keep copies
of medical records for dog hybrids that include the required information including the identifying information of the animal,
all preventative and routine husbandry procedures performed, information about problems identified, the plan for
treatment and care, treatments and/or vaccinations administered, and results of all tests performed.
Correct by 03/15/2024.

There is standing water in approximately 25 percent of the outdoor portion of the lemur enclosure while the remaining
area is wet and damp. Furthermore, approximately 90 percent of the heated shelter’s dirt floor has standing water while
the remaining area is wet and/or muddy. The last rain occurred two days prior to this inspection indicating poor drainage
within this enclosure. Improper drainage systems and standing water where the animals are contained may result in
noxious odors, spreading of diseases, insect infestation, and/or other health hazards. Housing facilities for non-human
primates must be constructed and maintained so that waste and water are rapidly eliminated to keep the animals dry,
minimize vermin and pest infestation, insects, odors, and disease hazards.
Correct by 3/15/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The disposition records are not current or complete at the time of inspection. There is no documentation available to 
review for the disposition of a zebra, a raccoon and three opossums that occurred since the last inspection. Accurate and 
complete acquisition and disposition records are necessary to allow for medical and legal tracking of the animals. The 
facility shall ensure that it makes, keeps, and maintains records which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning all exhibition animals: name and address of person from whom an animal was acquired, their USDA license 
number or Driver's license number/state, the name and address of the disposition of the animal, the date of acquisition 
and/or disposition, and the species of the animal. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
The facility has not yet completely developed and documented a contingency plan. A written contingency plan is required 
to help ensure animal health and well-being in the event of an emergency or disaster; without this tool, animals may suffer 
illness, injury, or death due to unpreparedness should an emergency or disaster strike. The licensee must develop, 
document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and 
care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. The plan must also be reviewed annually, and all 
employees trained on the plan within 30 days of employment. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Medical records were incomplete for both dog hybrids. Per the licensee, “Luna” and “Kuda” were both prescribed a 
monthly heartworm medication but there is no medical record showing any medication was prescribed or any treatments 
were given. Also, "Kuda" was prescribed an ear medication on January 10, 2023, with no record of doses being given by 
the licensee. The licensee stated all medications had been given as prescribed. Medical recordkeeping is important for 
ensuring the dog hybrids receive correct and complete medical care as well as assist with monitoring. Incomplete records 
can lead to missed or incorrect treatments, which can cause medical conditions to worsen. The facility shall keep copies 
of medical records for dog hybrids that include the required information including the identifying information of the animal,

all preventative and routine husbandry procedures performed, information about problems identified, the plan for 
treatment and care, treatments and/or vaccinations administered, and results of all tests performed. 
Correct by 03/15/2024. 
3.75(f) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There is standing water in approximately 25 percent of the outdoor portion of the lemur enclosure while the remaining 
area is wet and damp. Furthermore, approximately 90 percent of the heated shelter’s dirt floor has standing water while 
the remaining area is wet and/or muddy. The last rain occurred two days prior to this inspection indicating poor drainage 
within this enclosure. Improper drainage systems and standing water where the animals are contained may result in 
noxious odors, spreading of diseases, insect infestation, and/or other health hazards. Housing facilities for non-human 
primates must be constructed and maintained so that waste and water are rapidly eliminated to keep the animals dry, 
minimize vermin and pest infestation, insects, odors, and disease hazards.  
Correct by 3/15/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
